intro: Fraxinus excelsior var. australis, commonly known as the southern ash, is a variant of the common ash native to southern Europe. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 15–25 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and ovate with serrated margins, turning golden in autumn. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clustered inflorescences, followed by winged samaras for seed dispersal. It prefers well-drained soils and is often found in mixed woodlands and along riverbanks.
